Authors: Kusumawardhana I., Tarigan W.P., Komsary K.C., Maulana Y.
Title: Dark tourism's products development: The cases of Fatahillah Dungeon and Taman Prasasti Museum
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kusumawardhana, I., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Tarigan, W.P., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Komsary, K.C., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Maulana, Y., Tourism Department, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Despite academic interest in the tourism industry, there is a more sophisticated set of practice and thinking that could distinguish tourism products between mass and niche. Dark tourism, as the niche of tourism offers an economic value for tourists' consumption that forged between reality and imagination. However, few studies were found to understand the realm of development of dark tourism varieties and attractions, which associated with death and suffering from lower political and ideology to the highest range while consuming it. Therefore, alongside the analytical thinking towards the product's typology and variety, the examination of both SWOT (Strength, Weaknesses, Opportunity, Threats) model and TOWS (Threat-Opportunity & Weakness-Strength) matrix, synchronize the sites' elaboration resources and capabilities in which the dark tourism's place and space operate. Both of the qualitative case studies of Fatahillah Dungeon and Taman Prasasti museum provide the research practice that emerges from the visitors' voices. The findings deliver undiscovered value for the product development initiative, where at the same time bids the model for the dark tourism's consumption in term of the value creation and experience that giving the sites' meaning in recognizing how 'dark' the product is and stand out from the mass. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Museums; Tourism; Analytical thinking; Economic values; Qualitative case studies; Resources and capabilities; Value creation; Leisure industry

Authors: Komsary K.C., Ernawati T., Hodijah A., Wardiana D.
Title: Internet of things (IoT) for energy efficiency in tourism-related industry
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Department of Tourism, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Informatics Engineering, Politeknik TEDC Bandung, Bandung, 40513, Indonesia; Informatics and Computer Engineering, Politeknik Negeri Bandung, Bandung, 40012, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Komsary, K.C., Department of Tourism, Faculty of Economics and Communication, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Ernawati, T., Informatics Engineering, Politeknik TEDC Bandung, Bandung, 40513, Indonesia; Hodijah, A., Informatics and Computer Engineering, Politeknik Negeri Bandung, Bandung, 40012, Indonesia; Wardiana, D., Informatics Engineering, Politeknik TEDC Bandung, Bandung, 40513, Indonesia
Abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) has been considered as an alternative solution to the problem of energy efficiency in the tourism industry. IoT can be applied in supporting an environmentally friendly tourism industry. This study aims to see the possibilities of implementing IoT in the tourism SMEs (small-medium enterprises) by designing a simple prototype of a light controlling device as a solution to reduce energy consumption in the tourism-related industry. The prototype was designed by collaborating IoT, mobile devices and sensors in an electronic device (microcontroller Atmega 328P-PU) for lighting control. Furthermore, the switching device can be operated using an Android-based smartphone. The black box test examining the functionality of an application without peering into its internal structures or workings was carried out in the system, both server and client. The test results indicate that the device is functional, and wider use of IoT in the tourism industry in Indonesia is possible with a breakthrough in exploring the use of information technology. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: Atmega 328P microcontroller; Internet of Things (IoT); Lights controlling
Funding Details:
Office of Technology Transfer and Procurement

Authors: Komsary K.C., Tarigan W.P., Wiyana T.
Title: Limits of acceptable change as tool for tourism development sustainability in Pangandaran West Java
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Tourism Destination Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. KH. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hotel Management Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. KH. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Komsary, K.C., Tourism Destination Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. KH. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Tarigan, W.P., Tourism Destination Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. KH. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wiyana, T., Hotel Management Department, Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jl. KH. Syahdan No. 9, Palmerah Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Pangandaran since 2006 has become a model of sustainable tourism development. A program aimed to empower local communities to prepare work plans and activities to enrich the various potential development of sustainable tourism. By empowering local community, business competition has led to the undesired development of the tourism sector. This becomes the concern of the negative impact of physical changes in the area. This study aims to identify and measure the acceptable changes (limits of acceptable change-LAC) of tourism development in Pangandaran to remain adaptable as a tourist attraction. This study considers how to determine acceptable levels of impact that occurs in the Pangandaran area. This method involves stakeholders in determining the values, issues, and concerns the acceptable levels of impact for this region. The result of acceptance rate then compared with the effects of the current state. Through review and analysis methods used in this study, the LAC situation in Pangandaran outlined. Results from this study are expected to identify indicators of sustainable development of tourism sector through LAC approach. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Competition; Java programming language; Business competition; Indicators of sustainable development; Physical changes; Sustainable tourism; Sustainable tourism development; Tourism development; Tourism sectors; Tourist attractions; Sustainable development

Authors: Subakti A.G., Komsary K.C., Khrisnamurti N.
Title: Experiential marketing implication on museum: A case study on house of sampoerna museum
Source title: Heritage, Culture and Society: Research agenda and best practices in the hospitality and tourism industry - Proceedings of the 3rd International Hospitality and Tourism Conference, IHTC 2016 and 2nd International Seminar on Tourism, ISOT 2016
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Jakarta State University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Subakti, A.G., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Komsary, K.C., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Khrisnamurti, N., Jakarta State University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Tourism in many aspects is involving many experiential activities. Museum is one of tourist attractions that arise visitors’ emotional experience. The visitor experience is important in terms of developing and managing museum to maintain visitors’ visit. This study tries to analyze visitors’ different types of experience and expectations when they visit museum through perceived value. The data is collected and analyzed using Schmitt’s experiential marketing approach and a questionnaire of visitor experience and expectations. Some related discussions were proposed at the end of this paper. © 2016 Taylor & Francis Group, London.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Marketing; Emotional experiences; Interpretation; Perceived value; Tourist attractions; Visitor experiences; Museums
